legend: DWeb Camp - The Seeds Are Planted. Mai and Benedict meet, recognizing the contradiction of writing about decentralization while publishing on centralized platforms.
The Distributed Press Idea is Born. Benedict, Mai, and Udit begin developing the concept: if you want to build a tool, build a magazine as proof of concept.
Grant for the Web. $50,000 Creative Commons Grant to build COMPOST Magazine as a proof-of-concept for decentralized publishing.
COMPOST Issue 01 launches. The first issue of COMPOST Magazine goes live, demonstrating the potential of decentralized publishing.
Distributed Press v0.1 Released. The first public release of Distributed Press, enabling websites to be published across HTTP, IPFS, and Hypercore protocols.
COMPOST Issue 02 published. Second issue demonstrates the growing maturity of the platform.
Filecoin Foundation Grant. FFDW provides crucial funding to expand Distributed Press infrastructure and capabilities.
API & Publisher Improvements. Major technical enhancements make Distributed Press more robust and easier to use.
Sutty Partnership Begins. Collaboration with Sutty CMS to integrate decentralized publishing into their platform.
Growing Adoption. Multiple publishers begin experimenting with Distributed Press for their content.
DP Social Inbox Launch. Major feature release enabling ActivityPub integration for decentralized social features.
Product-Market Fit Challenges. Despite technical success, adoption remains limited due to industry inertia and resource constraints.
Building the Road as We Travel. FFDW grant concludes. Hypha commits to maintaining the architecture while reflecting on lessons learned.
The Journey Continues. The infrastructure remains available, and the vision of decentralized publishing lives on.
